It was unclear whether other investors would join the city pension funds and vote against Wal-Mart's directors. Board members at some large public companies have come under fire from shareholders at annual meetings this year, but most of the opposition has been related to executive pay practices. It is unusual for board members to be unseated by a shareholder vote.

2012-04-30.snippet: The refinery near Philadelphia, being acquired from ConocoPhillips for $150 million, is meant to offset the risk of higher jet fuel prices....
2012-04-30.lead_paragraph: Delta Air Lines said on Monday that it had agreed to buy a refinery near Philadelphia from ConocoPhillips to offset the risk of higher jet fuel prices. Delta said that it would spend $150 million to acquire the Trainer refinery, which has been shuttered for six months, after receiving $30 million from the state of Pennsylvania as part of a deal to support job creation.
2012-04-30.abstract: Delta Air Lines will buy the Trainer refinery near Philadelphia from ConocoPhillips for $150 million to offset the risk of higher jet fuel prices. Photos (M)

headline.main: Delta Buys Refinery to Get Control of Fuel Costs

2012-04-30.snippet: One-way tickets and convoluted routes are two of the strategies one business traveler uses to work the system for the lowest airfares....
2012-04-30.lead_paragraph: MICHAEL H. SOMMER was on the phone the other day from the airport in Salt Lake City, explaining how he saved a lot of money on his trip home to Jacksonville, Fla. ''From Salt Lake to Jacksonville, it's like $450 one way,'' Mr. Sommer said. ''So, instead I'm going Salt Lake to New York for $119, and then New York to Jacksonville for around $100, both one-way tickets.''
2012-04-30.abstract: Joe Sharkey On the Road column notes one-way tickets and convoluted routes are two of the strategies one business traveler uses to work the system for the lowest airfares. Drawing (M)

headline.main: Flying a Circuitous Route May Land the Best Airfare

2012-04-30.snippet: With controversy building over its role in a Mexican bribery scandal, Wal-Mart’s desire to stay out of the limelight grows....
2012-04-30.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- Besides its success in selling goods that range from groceries to televisions, Wal-Mart has also shown a highly developed ability to sell itself. The country's biggest retailer has adroitly used millions of dollars in campaign contributions, charity drives, lobbying campaigns, and its work for popular causes like childhood nutrition and carbon emissions to build support in Congress and the White House.
2012-04-30.abstract: Controversy is building over Wal-Mart's role in a Mexican bribery scandal, and the company's desire to stay out of the limelight will now be put to a test; to help weather the fallout, company will rely on the relationships it has worked assiduously to develop in Washington during the last decade--relationships that its critics say have insulated it from political threats. Photo (M)

headline.main: Wal-Mart's Good-Citizen Efforts Face a Test

2012-04-30.snippet: John Mulliken is co-founder and general manager of jossandmain.com, a daily deals site offering items for the home....
2012-04-30.lead_paragraph: I USED to hate business travel. For six years, I flew so much that I was in the top tier of mileage for all the major airlines. At one point, I was flying to Europe nearly every week for most of a year. There was a woman in security at La Guardia who started to recognize me. One time she actually asked me if I was an air marshal. I think it's because I had this special way of going through security. I could take off my shoes and belt and then put my computer on the belt in this really fluid move.
2012-04-30.abstract: Frequent Flier column features jossandmain.com co-founder John Mulliken discussing his flying experiences. Photo (M)5
